ASIAN DEVELOPMENT BANK TAR:NEP 34308 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
(Financed by Japan Special Fund) 
 
 
TO THE 
 
 
KINGDOM OF NEPAL 
 
 
FOR PREPARING THE 
 
 
COMMERCIAL AGRICULTURE DEVELOPMENT PROJECT 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
October 2002

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 22 October 2002) 
 
Currency Unit –  Nepalese rupee (NRe/NRs) 
NRe1.00 =  $0.130 
$1.00 =  NRs76.733 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  BME  –  benefit monitoring and evaluation 
  DDC  –  district development committee 
  DOA  –  Department of Agriculture 
  GDI  –  gender-related development index 
  HDI  –  human development index 
  IEE  –  initial environmental examination 
  IPSA  –  Initial Poverty and Social Analysis 
  NGO  –  nongovernment organization 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  TOR  –  terms of reference 
  VDC  –  village development committee 
  WTO  –  World Trade Organization 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
NOTES 
 
(i)  The fiscal year (FY) of the Government ends on 15 July.  
(ii)  In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
This report was prepared by a team consisting of Pratima Dayal, Team Leader; Snimer 
Sahni,  Sr.  Project  Economist;  Govinda  Gewali,  Project  Implementation  Officer;  and 
Melinda Good, Counsel.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of Nepal requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide 
project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  formulate  the  Commercial  Agriculture 
Development Project.1 The TA was included in ADB’s 2002 country program for Nepal,2 and a 
Fact-Finding Mission was fielded from 1 to 12 July 2002. The Mission met with concerned 
government  agencies,  bilateral  and  multilateral  development  partners,  nongovernment 
organizations (NGOs), and the private sector; traveled to the Eastern Region of Nepal to 
interact with farmers; and conducted a stakeholder workshop to ascertain a cross-section of 
views on the focus and scope of the proposed Project. Based on this consultation, the Mission 
reached an understanding with the Government on the objective, scope, cost estimates and 
financing plan, implementation arrangements, and outline terms of reference for the TA. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Nepal continues to be one of the poorest countries of the world, with a per capita income of 
$249 per year.3 The country’s population is 22.7 million, of whom 42% are below the poverty line 
and have an annual income of less than NRs4,400 (approximately $56) per capita. Poverty is 
widespread but is predominantly a rural phenomenon, with over 90% of the country’s poor living in 
rural areas. Agriculture is the primary employer of the labor force (about 80%), accounts for about 
40% of the national gross domestic product, but has largely remained subsistence and focused on 
food crops. The total arable land in the country is 2.9 million hectares (ha), but, due to high 
population pressure, the average landholding is small (0.9 ha in 1990/91) and further diminishing. 
Consequently, growth in the agricultural gross domestic product, has been less than 2% annually 
through most of the last decade, and the upswing that was noted in 2000 (5%) has yet to stabilize.4 
 
3.  Nepal exhibits a wide range of topography and climate across three major ecological 
zones: the plain areas (Terai), the hills, and the mountains. The diversity of temperature and 
rainfall5 in these regions offers a unique opportunity for growing a number of higher value crops 
such as vegetables, fruits, spices, tea, and nontimber forest products. The Government is fully 
cognizant of agriculture’s importance in the country’s economy and therefore developed, with 
ADB assistance, a long-term growth plan for the sector, the Agriculture Perspective Plan,6 
adopted in 1995. This plan recognizes agriculture as the engine of economic growth and the 
means to reduce the country’s poverty; it espouses a prioritized package approach comprising 
the  following  key  elements  (i)  infrastructure  (irrigation,  rural  roads,  and  electricity);  (ii) 
appropriate institutional framework; and (iii) access to priority inputs (fertilizer, seed, and credit). 
The country’s Ninth Five-Year Plan (1997-2002) further underlines the need to improve returns 
and incomes from agriculture through diversification into high-value crops, especially in areas 
that have agroecological advantages and accessibility to key infrastructure. In many of these 
respects, the Eastern Region is particularly well suited. This strategy of diversification to high-
value  crops  and  commercialization,  including  the  integration  and  promotion  of  production, 
postharvest/processing, and marketing activities for increasing financial returns from agriculture, 
is supported by the Tenth Five-Year Plan (2002-2007), the agriculture markets study,7 and the 
                                                 
1  Listed in the Country Strategy and Program 2002 as “Integrated Agriculture Development Project,” but the title was 
changed during fact-finding at the Government’s request to clarify the Project's intent and focus. 
2  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (Internet) on 24 April 2002. 
3  National Population Census 2001. 
4  ADB. 2001. Nepal Country Economic Review. Manila.  
5  Annual rainfall varies between 1,500 and 2,500 millimeters, being higher in the eastern parts, and 60-80% of it falls 
during the monsoon season from June to September. 
6  ADB. 1993. Technical Assistance to Nepal for Preparing the Agriculture Perspective Plan. Manila. 
7  Japan International Cooperation Agency. 2001. Study on the Agricultural Marketing Development Project in the 
Kingdom of Nepal.

2 
recommendations of the Agriculture Sector Performance Review.8 The latter has confirmed the 
potential for commercial production of high-value crops in many parts of Nepal and suggests 
commercialization of agriculture as the key strategy for improving returns and incomes from the 
sector.  The  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency  study  has  additionally  highlighted  the 
ecological and infrastructure potential of the Central and Eastern regions to produce crops such 
as vegetables and vegetable seeds, spices, fruits, flowers, tea, and nontimber forest products. 
 
4.  Both the Government and its development partners have made substantial investments 
in the agriculture sector in the last two decades, and more than 200 projects have been 
implemented, with support from ADB (about $350 million), the World Bank (about $170 million), 
and other multilateral and bilateral agencies (about $311 million).9 Compared with the other 
regions in the country, the Eastern and Central regions have received more investments from 
external agencies, particularly for rural development, agriculture, irrigation, and roads. As a 
result,  many  hill  districts  and  hinterland  areas  of  these  regions  are  accessible  and  well 
connected with major highways (East-West highway, North-South Mechi and Kosi highways) 
and feeder roads. In addition, three road projects are ongoing and one is in the pipeline, all of 
which will further improve connections within and between districts.10 Similarly, many irrigation 
sector projects have developed both groundwater and surface-based irrigation systems in these 
areas. The proposed Project will capitalize on previous and ongoing infrastructure investments 
to promote commercial agriculture in the region. 
 
5.  Major policy reforms were undertaken under the Second Agriculture Program Loan11 and 
the fertilizer subsector was deregulated, fertilizer subsidies removed, and the private sector 
allowed to freely import and distribute fertilizers. Additionally, the Government removed the 
capital cost subsidy on shallow tubewells and agreed to gradually rationalize the subsidy on deep 
tubewells and surface irrigation, and to privatize the Agriculture Inputs Corporation (previously the 
sole  public  sector  importer  and  distributor  of  fertilizers).  A  competitive  grant  system  was 
introduced12 in 2001 to improve the effectiveness and quality of agricultural research. Policies 
and guidelines for implementing agriculture programs in partnership with NGOs and the private 
sector have been in place since 2001, and a group approach in farm-related activities has been 
encouraged by the Government, be it for water management or for management of crops or 
livestock.  The  devolution  of  power  to  the  village  and  district  development  committees  for 
planning and implementing agriculture programs is also planned for 2003 under the Local Self-
Governance Act of 1999. The overall policy environment therefore appears to be favorable for 
promoting high-value agriculture in partnership with farmers and the private sector. 
 
6.  The Eastern Region of Nepal has been identified as the project area because of its 
accessibility  to  main  highways  and  markets;  its  favorable  agroecological  environment  for 
producing high-value crops;13 the increasing interest of the farming community in producing 
vegetables, fruits, and spices;14 and the opportunity for synergy with other external investments. 
                                                 
8  ADB. 1993. Technical Assistance to Nepal for Preparing the Agriculture Sector Performance Review. Manila. 
9  These figures represent investment volumes since 1990. Source: Ministry of Finance, December 2001. 
10 The Rural Access Project (Department for International Development); the Rural Development Program (GTZ 
[Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit―German Agency for Technical Cooperation]). ADB. 
Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on Proposed Loans to the Kingdom of 
Nepal for the Rural Infrastructure Development Project. Manila.  ADB. 1996. Technical Assistance to Nepal for 
Preparing the Second Rural Infrastructure Sector Project. Manila. 
11 ADB. 1998. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan to the 
Kingdom of Nepal for the Second Agriculture Program. Manila. 
12 ADB. 2000. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan to the 
Kingdom of Nepal for the Crop Diversification Project. Manila. 
13 The Mission and Government agreed to keep the project area limited to one region so that it can be cohesive, can 
be effectively planned and implemented, and its impact maximized.  
14 Mission consultations with farmers and observations during field visits to farmers' fields and markets.

3 
The Eastern Region consists of 5 Terai and 11 hill districts and has the highest population 
density (366 persons per square kilometer [km2]) in the country (more than double the average 
density of 158 persons/km2). While the region’s overall Human Development Index of 0.484 is 
the second highest among the five regions in Nepal, it is still low compared with neighboring 
countries like India (0.571) and Pakistan (0.498).15 Also, many of the hill districts of the region 
are classified as food-deficit areas, and two of the Terai districts (Siraha and Saptari) are reported to 
be at par in terms of poverty and deprivation indexes, with districts in the Midwestern Region (Humla 
and Jajarkot). Increasing economic returns to the farmers in this region through commercialization of 
high-value agriculture, is therefore very appropriate at this point in its development. 
 
7.  The Partnership Agreement on Poverty Reduction (October 2001) between the Government 
and ADB confirms continued support for implementation of the Agriculture Perspective Plan, 
which  aims  at  reducing  rural  poverty  through  increasing  agriculture  sector  production  and 
productivity, and diversification to higher value crops. The 2002 Country Strategy and Program 
Update notes recent improvements in agricultural performance due to the improved policy 
environment, more market-oriented systems for inputs and outputs, and greater participation of 
stakeholders, and restates the continued strategy for support to poverty reduction through a 
combination of accelerated, broad-based economic growth (especially of agriculture) and good 
governance. The proposed Project is therefore consistent with the Government’s agriculture 
policy and ADB’s country and poverty reduction strategies, as enunciated in the Government’s 
Tenth  Five-Year  Plan,  the  Partnership  Agreement  on  Poverty  Reduction  between  the 
Government and ADB, and ADB’s 2002 Country Strategy and Program Update. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
8.  The TA will assist the Government in designing an investment project suitable for external 
financing that will focus on enhancing income and employment opportunities through increased and 
sustainable commercialization of agriculture. It will promote production, processing, and marketing of 
high-value crops, and capacity building of all stakeholders in order to support and sustain the process. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
9.  The  TA  and  the  ensuing  Project  will  target  promoting  high-value  crop  production, 
improving postharvest processes, and strengthening market development. Close attention will 
be paid to identifying market failures in commercial agriculture, processing, and marketing that 
need to be addressed through public investments, private sector participation, public-private 
partnerships, a conducive economic and policy environment, and strengthened capacity of both 
the  public  and  private  sector  (including  NGOs)  to  deliver  inputs  and  support  services  for 
commercialized agriculture production. Consideration will also be given to creating high-value 
production clusters to facilitate marketing and processing of products. 
 
10.  The main beneficiaries of the Project will be the farmers (including sharecroppers and 
women farmers) growing or interested in growing high-value crops such as vegetables, fruits, 
and spices, and entrepreneurs located in the identified high potential areas of the Terai and the 
hill districts of the Eastern Region. Since women constitute more than 75% of the agricultural 
labor  force,  the  TA  will  identify  means  of  facilitating  their  full  participation  and  ensuring 
commensurate benefits to them. The potential districts have been identified because of their 
agroclimatic suitability for high-value crop production, and the availability of irrigation and road 
infrastructure created through previous government and external investments. The Project will 
                                                 
15 See summary initial poverty and social analysis in Appendix 1 for more details.

4 
incorporate  the  lessons  learned  from  past  projects  and  will  build  synergy  with  past  and 
upcoming investments in the sector, following the directives of the Tenth Five-Year Plan. 
 
11.  The key activities of the Project will include (i) technology development and dissemination to 
farmers  and  entrepreneurs  for  high-value  crop  production,  postharvest  management,  and 
processing; (ii) market development including (a) market infrastructure especially for hinterland 
areas,  (b)  market  information  collection  and  dissemination  systems,  and  (c)  improved  market 
management; (iii) capacity building for (a) farmers (both technical and organizational), and (b) 
service providers (government agencies, local bodies, NGOs, and the private sector―technical, 
managerial, and institutional); (iv) facilitating access to credit; (v) supplementing infrastructure funds 
for local bodies/farmer associations to address critical gaps in existing facilities, for example, trail 
bridges;  and  (vi)  project  management  support  especially  for  improved  planning,  intersector 
coordination, monitoring, and impact evaluation. The TA will be implemented using an effective 
participatory methodology to deal with the complexities and interdependencies inherent in the 
agricultural production sector and to ensure the full involvement and commitment of potential 
beneficiaries and other stakeholders in developing the project design. A holistic approach will be 
taken  including  consideration  of  issues  of  security,  decentralization  of  government  authority, 
environmental concerns, gender and social aspects, and competitiveness with external markets. 
Beneficiaries and other stakeholders will be identified early in the study. 
 
12.  The TA will prepare a project in 11 districts of the Eastern Region of Nepal including the 
6 hill districts of Dhankota, Ilam, Panchthar, Taplejung, Terathum, and Udayapur16 and all 5 
districts of the Terai: Jhapa, Morang, Saptari, Siraha, and Sunsari. Consideration will be given 
during  the  TA  implementation  to  the  inclusion  of  the  remaining  5  hill  districts  of  Bhojpur, 
Khotang,  Okhaldhunga,  Sankhuwasabha,  and  Solukhumbu,  but  this  will  be  subject  to  the 
completion of road links to these districts and other agreed upon eligibility criteria. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $825,000 equivalent, of which the foreign exchange 
cost is $510,000 and the local currency cost is $315,000 equivalent. ADB will provide $700,000 
equivalent to finance the entire foreign exchange cost and $190,000 equivalent of the local currency 
cost. The TA will be financed by ADB on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the 
Government  of  Japan.  The  Government  will  contribute  the  remaining  local  currency  cost  of 
$125,000 equivalent to provide office accommodation, counterpart staff support, field transport, 
facilities for seminars and meetings, and other administrative expenses. The Government has 
assured the availability of counterpart services and facilities by the expected commencement date of 
the TA. Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. The Government has 
been informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to financing an ensuing loan project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  The Department of Agriculture (DOA) will be the Executing Agency and will establish a 
TA implementation unit based in Kathmandu. DOA will appoint a full-time TA project coordinator 
and provide the unit with (i) sufficient counterpart and support staff for overall support; (ii) local 
transportation  of  consultants  and  government  counterparts;  (iii)  office  space,  utilities,  and 
furnishings; (iv) assistance with surveys, stakeholder workshops and participatory exercises; 
and (v) local communication facilities. DOA will also provide assistance for local transportation 
of  consultants  and  government  counterparts,  and  for  surveys,  stakeholder  workshops,  and 
participatory exercises. The TA project coordinator will coordinate TA implementation with concerned 
government ministries and agencies, NGOs, the private sector, aid agencies, and other stakeholders 
                                                 
16 These districts are all linked with the North-South and the East-West highway, which runs across the country.

5 
as required. DOA will also form a TA advisory group, which will work in close collaboration with the TA 
consultants to develop the project strategies and design. The group will be chaired by the director 
general of DOA and will consist of stakeholder representatives (including potential beneficiaries). 
 
15.  The TA will be implemented over a 6-month period, from February 2003 to July 2003, and 
will be in three phases (see implementation schedule in Appendix 3). Phase I (1 month) will prepare 
a work plan, collect and review sector information including lessons learned, and use a local 
institution to undertake rapid rural appraisals and prepare a detailed poverty and social assessment. 
Phase II (3.5 months) will include participatory planning, fieldwork, project design, and development 
of individual components. Phase III (1.5 months) will finalize the preparation of the feasibility study 
for an investment project. Three tripartite meetings will be organized during TA implementation (at 
inception, at midterm, and at the draft final report stage), to be chaired by the secretary of the 
Ministry of Agriculture and Cooperatives and attended by DOA, ADB, and the consultants. 
 
16.  A total of about 42 person-months of consulting services, including 18 person-months of 
international and 24 person-months of domestic consultants, will be recruited through a firm. The 
international  consultants  will  have  expertise  in  (i)  agriculture  project  management  including 
monitoring and evaluation (team leader), (ii) agricultural economics, (iii) agricultural marketing and 
market information, (iv) postharvest and agribusiness development, (v) high-value crop production, 
and (vi) participatory planning and systems learning. The domestic consultants, to be provided by an 
associating firm, will have experience in (i) institutional development and local governance (deputy 
team leader), (ii) social development and gender (iii) market infrastructure architecture/engineering, 
(iv) agricultural research and extension, (v) on-farm water management, (vi) agricultural credit, (vii) 
partnership development, and (viii) environmental assessment. The international team leader and 
the domestic deputy team leader will provide overall management of the consulting team. The 
general terms of reference for the consultants are attached in Appendix 4. 
 
17.  A local institution will be recruited, in accordance with arrangements acceptable to ADB, 
for the equivalent of 4 person-months to conduct a detailed rural and social analysis, review and 
confirm the suitability of proposed project areas, identify stakeholders, and carry out a baseline 
survey. The institution will have extensive local experience and proven capacity to undertake 
the said task. (A summary initial poverty and social analysis is given in Appendix 1). 
 
18.  Selection and engagement of the TA consultants will be undertaken in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB on the 
engagement of domestic consultants. The consultants will be selected using ADB's simplified 
technical proposal using quality and cost-based selection procedures. The TA will provide 
equipment such as computers and other office equipment, which the consultant will purchase in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. Equipment so procured will be handed over 
to DOA upon completion of the TA. The TA will also provide funds for workshops and surveys to 
be  conducted  by  the  consultants  in  accordance  with  arrangements  suitable  to  ADB.  The 
consultants will conduct at least two stakeholder workshops and prepare (i) an inception report 
at  the  end  of  Phase  I,  (ii)  an  interim  report  for  the  midterm  review  2  months  after  the 
commencement of Phase II, (iii) a draft final report at the end of Phase II, and (iv) a final report 
at the conclusion of the consulting services. All reports will be submitted to the advisory group, 
the Government, and ADB. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Nepal for preparing the Commercial Agriculture Development Project, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

6  Appendix 1 
SUMMARY INITIAL POVERTY AND SOCIAL ANALYSIS REPORT FORM1 
 
A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis 
Sector identified as a National Priority in Country     Yes  Sector identified as a National Priority in           Yes      
Poverty Analysis?  Country Poverty Partnership Agreement? 
 
Contribution of the sector/ subsector to reduce poverty in Nepal 
Agriculture accounts for 40% of the gross domestic product. The country ranks 129 out of 162 countries and has a 
human development index (HDI) of 0.48―lower than the weighted average for South Asia (0.554). The HDI of rural 
areas (0.446) is much lower than the HDI of urban areas (0.616), and the gender-related development index (GDI) 
follows the same pattern, with a GDI of 0.426 for rural and 0.605 for urban areas2. Similarly, the index for rural poverty 
(41.4) is almost twice as high as that for urban poverty (23.9) and it varies widely across ecological regions. The 
population growth rate increased from 2.1% in 1991 to 2.3% in 2001, with the increase concentrated in rural areas, rural 
women having more than twice as many children (4.4) as urban women (2.1). Lack of commensurate growth in 
employment opportunities due to poor economic growth has forced many rural poor into subsistence activities on forest 
and marginal lands, often with negative environmental impacts. It is clear that in the context of Nepal, where about 80% 
of the labor force relies on agriculture for employment, no economic growth and poverty reduction are possible without 
improving the performance of the agriculture sector. Attention and energy also need to be focused on fostering 
ownership and competency among locally owned and managed farmer groups so that completed infrastructure is 
efficiently maintained and operated to increase agricultural productivity. The Tenth Plan envisages achieving pro-poor 
growth by giving top priority to agriculture and achieving broad-based growth through implementation of the Agriculture 
Perspective Plan. 
 
The Terai areas of the Eastern Development Region have the highest population density (366 persons per square 
kilometer [km2]), more than double the average density of 158 persons per km2 for the whole of Nepal. While the 
Eastern Development Region has the second highest HDI (0.484) of the five development regions, all of the hill districts 
under the proposed Project are classified as food deficit areas.  The poverty and deprivation indexes of Siraha and 
Saptari (in the Terai) are comparable to Humla and Jajarkot of the Midwestern Development Region. In addition, at 
least three of the hill districts (Ilam, Panchthar, and Taplejung) have identified pockets3 of poverty where lack of inputs, 
inadequate service provision, and poor market access have led to low levels of agricultural productivity and consequent 
labor migration out of the area to India. Some of the lowest cropping intensities in the country occur in the eastern hill 
districts, and wide variations in cropping intensity have been reported in the proposed Terai districts as well. It is 
envisaged to integrate the farmers from the hinterland into the mainstream economy so that they can benefit directly 
from the growth process by taking advantage of social and economic opportunities arising out of expanded market 
linkages. Market collection centers are proposed to be developed in the rural hinterland with the intention of linking rural 
farmers to the markets beyond their immediate village. The Project will promote income growth by motivating farmers to 
be involved in the production, processing, and marketing of high-value crops and  will thereby contribute towards 
reducing poverty in the Eastern Development Region by creating opportunities through expansion of market linkages 
and facilities, and securing good returns on past investments on irrigation and rural road networks. The proportion of 
households that convert to high-value vegetable crop production will also impact on the nutritional status of the family 
and the region, through improved availability of fruits and vegetables. From a poverty vantage point, high-value crops 
have been reported to be attractive for households with less than 0.25 hectare (ha) because of their short gestation 
periods, high returns, and a regular source of income for poor households, when marketed. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis        Proposed Classification: Economic Growth 
                    Gender and Development 
The proposed project districts include 11 districts in the Eastern Development Region where a supportive environment 
exists to open and expand marketing potentials. These include six hill districts (Dhankota, Ilam, Panchthar, Taplejung, 
Terathum, and Udayapur) and five Terai districts (Jhapa, Morang, Saptari, Siraha, and Sunsari,). Poverty pockets exist, 
both across and within districts. In the Terai, the average farm size is larger (1.29 ha) than in the hills (0.77 ha). In 
addition, farms in the hills comprise on average four parcels that are often scattered, which has impeded efficient land 
use and farm labor. Topographical constraints and resource endowments affect the face of poverty. Household food 
shortage and unemployment remain major risks to the majority of the people. Coping strategies include male migration 
to India in search of wage labor to meet demand for cash, with the result that women are saddled with additional 
responsibilities, and become primary decision makers both at the household and farm level, especially among low-
                                                 
1   An initial poverty and social analysis for the proposed Commercial Agriculture Development Project was undertaken with the 
objective of determining the scope of poverty and social/gender issues that will need to be addressed during the design process. 
The initial poverty and social analysis entailed field visits to Morang and Sunsari districts in eastern Nepal, and consultations with 
potential beneficiaries and other stakeholders including line agency officials and representatives of local governance structures. 
2   UNDP 2001. Nepal Human Development Report 2001. Kathmandu, Nepal. 
3  SNV Netherlands Development Organization, 1997. District Profiles of Ilam, Panchthar and Taplejung. Kathmandu, Nepal.

Appendix 1  7 
income households. The project preparatory technical assistance (TA) will identify such pockets, and determine total 
population and the mix therein, with a view to (i) assessing the distribution of benefits, direct and indirect, on different 
categories of farmers, small and large, women, and disadvantaged groups; (ii) facilitating cooperation between traders, 
and women and men producers; and (iii) recommending establishing a market information system covering both formal 
and informal markets catering to literate and illiterate farmers. The TA will also identify the best locations for collection 
centers and other market infrastructure and assess their feasibility. Such strategically located collection centers are 
intended to expand rural farmers’ access to larger market centers, increase their access to information on marketing 
alternatives, and encourage better linkages between producers and manufacturers/traders of selected products in order 
to facilitate direct negotiation of prices and avoid exploitation by middlemen. The Project will ensure that small and 
marginal farmers also participate and benefit from it by soliciting their participation in farmer groups (associations, 
women’s groups, self help, and user groups) and building the organizational capacity of such groups to provide better 
service to their members, and increasing their capability to manage risks themselves. The TA will assess the social 
capital of farmer/user groups/organizations, including their structural characteristics, identify existing groups and assess 
how they operate (membership recruitment, size, federations, and type of leadership roles), and identify group 
organizational strengthening needs. The capacity-building program for farmer groups would also explore mechanisms 
to increase the institutional capability of the group to network, establish market linkages, expand market information, 
and increase members’ access to new techniques. In addition, differences will need to be considered between and 
within groups to ensure the largest coverage and equitable benefits. 
 
Low levels of human development in rural areas warrant a clear need for involving community-based organizations, 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs) and the private sector in working with the people. NGOs in the country vary 
considerably in their effectiveness and scope, and also their leanings. For those that are effective, their strength lies in 
their ability to provide intensive support and guidance, compared with what government departments provide (more 
than two junior technical assistants per village development committee [VDC] compared with one junior technical 
assistant per 3-4 VDCs by the district agriculture department). Their major strength is their trust by local communities 
and their fluency in the local language. Their main weakness relates to "politicization" and dependency on one or two 
key persons. The TA will need to assess the strength of existing community-based organizations and NGOs, especially 
those operating in the region, in delivering services envisaged under the Project and also to develop modalities about 
how they would complement the government effort. 
 
C.  Participation Process 
Stakeholder Analysis  
Since stakeholders influence the achievement of project objectives, the TA will identify at the outset all potential 
stakeholders with a view to delineating primary and secondary stakeholders. This includes identification of groups and 
may include but not be limited to farmer/user groups, cooperatives, local community-based organizations; individual 
traders (wholesalers and retailers); representatives of local governance structures (VDC/district development committee 
[DDC]); central and district line ministries; locally based civil society organizations, farmer cooperatives, NGOs; and 
umbrella groups representing members from the private sector such as local chapters of chamber of commerce. 
Poverty and social assessment teams will conduct field consultations over 1 month using rapid rural appraisal and 
participatory rapid assessment techniques, in addition to conducting base line surveys and gender analysis, identifying 
stakeholders, and initiating social mobilization. The TA will also assist in identifying individuals to represent the various 
stakeholder groups and ensure that they are represented in balance. The Project will apply a participatory and systems 
learning approach involving stakeholders and their representatives so that the project design represents a consensus of 
all stakeholders. Two workshops will be conducted, one at the beginning of the fieldwork and the other at the end of the 
fieldwork to consolidate views and recommendations for the project design. 
 
Participation strategy required                                                                                                                       No

men  and  women.  This  will  entail  determining  the 
executing/implementation  agency’s  (EA/IA)  ability  to  address 
gender concerns, gender capacity/building needs of the EA/IA, 
district line agencies, VDC members, farmer groups, women and 
men, and resource requirements.  
Affordability  None    No 
Labor  Nonsignificant  The Project foresees incremental employment generation through  No 
increased production and commercialization of high-value crops. 
However, no major impact of the project is envisaged on the labor 
market.  
Indigenous  Uncertain  The  eastern  hill  districts  are  populated  by  two  main  linguistic   
People  groupings: Tibeto-Burman and Indo-Aryan speaking populations. 
The former comprise many distinct groups, of which two groups 
(the Limbus and Rais) have inhabited the area for over 1300 years 
and comprise 40-60% of the population. Historically, these groups 
held all agricultural land as common property with right to lease, but 
this  system  of  land  ownership  was  abolished  in  1964  and 
communal  lands  was  assigned  to  individuals.  The  Indo-Aryan 
people came later and are organized in an occupation based caste 
system prevalent in India, which places the Brahmin-Chettri group 
(traditional  teacher)  at  the  top  and  the  occupation  castes  like 
cobblers, tailors, and blacksmiths at the bottom. The project design 
centers  on  detailed  social  analysis  and  participatory  systems 
learning approach and therefore the process will ensure that issues 
and concerns of any ethnic minorities or disadvantaged groups are 
addressed and project benefits are equally accessed. 
Other Risks/  Nonsignificant  The effective use of participatory planning approaches will ensure  No 
Vulnerabilities  full  participation  of  all  stakeholders  in  the  design  process  and 
thereby any potential risks or vulnerabilities will be addressed and 
commitment and ownership ensured in the ensuing Project.

Appendix 4  11 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Phase  I―Planning  and  Organization,  Information  Gathering,  Rural  Appraisal, 
Social Assessment, Stakeholder Identification, and Baseline Data Collection (1 
month) 
1.  Phase I will begin prior to the fielding of the main group of consultants. The team leader 
(international  agriculture  project  management/monitoring  and  evaluation  specialist)  and  the 
deputy team leader (domestic institutional development and local governance specialist), will 
perform the following: 
(i)  Review the terms of reference for the technical assistance (TA) and relevant 
documents such as implementation reviews of the Crop Diversification Project, 
the Agriculture Perspective Plan, the Agriculture Sector Performance Review, 
studies and plans for the devolution of authority to local governance entities, 
poverty  reduction  and  gender  issues,  monitoring  and  evaluation  and  the 
agriculture sector in Nepal, and the Five Year Plans. Commence dialogue on the 
implementation  of  the  TA  for  the  preparation  of  a  Commercial  Agriculture 
Development Project and the need for a changing role for the Department of 
Agriculture (DOA). With the Planning Commission, Ministry of Agriculture and 
Cooperatives, and related sector officials begin the review and assessment of the 
management, monitoring, and evaluation of activities in the agriculture sector. 
(ii)  Prepare the detailed draft work plan, approach and methodologies to be used in 
preparing the feasibility study for the new project. 
(iii)  Ensure that the social analysis/mobilization team fully understand their terms of 
reference (TOR) and oversee the commencement of their fieldwork. Assist them, 
with  the  support  of  DOA,  in  the  confirmation  of  project  districts  and  the 
identification of beneficiaries and stakeholder representatives to participate in the 
advisory group and first stakeholder workshop. 
(iv)  Assist  the  participatory  planning/systems  learning  specialist  in  making 
arrangements for the orientation and team building of the combined consultant 
team, for the first stakeholder workshop, and for the formation of the advisory 
group. 
2.  The social analysis/mobilization team, with the assistance and guidance from the team 
leader and deputy team leader, will carry out the following tasks: 
(i)  Conduct a rapid rural appraisal and detailed social and poverty assessment, 
following the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) guidelines in its Handbook on 
Poverty and Social Analysis, of the tentatively selected project areas, and confirm 
their suitability for inclusion in the Project. Assist in the selection of suitable 
representatives for participation in the advisory group. Carry out other tasks as 
detailed in the team’s specific TOR. 
(ii)  Initiate  baseline  agricultural  surveys  of  the  selected  project  areas  and 
recommend appropriate mechanisms for benefit monitoring and evaluation (BME) 
to  be  included  in  the  ensuing  Project,  using  ADB’s  Handbook  on  Benefit 
Monitoring and Evaluation for guidance.  
(iii)  Prepare  a  briefing  report  covering  the  details  and  findings  of  the  activities 
conducted under the team’s specific TOR. 
3.  The participatory planning/systems learning specialist will be fielded 1 week prior to the 
end of Phase I and will have the following responsibilities: (i) assist in the conduct of team-

12  Appendix 4 
building exercises for the consultants; (ii) introduce the participatory methodology to the project 
design and development process in the formation of the advisory group; and (iii) prepare for the 
initial workshop, to be carried out at the beginning of Phase II. 
B.  Phase  II―Stakeholder  Workshops,  Team  Building,  Fieldwork,  and  Project 
Preparation (3.5 months) 
4.  Phase II will begin with the fielding of the main group of international and domestic 
consultants following the completion of Phase I. The consultants (international and domestic), 
working in collaboration with government counterparts and the advisory group, will have the 
following responsibilities: 
(i)  Conduct  an  initial  workshop  to  develop  a  common  vision  for  the  future 
development of the agriculture sector, focusing on commercialization and income 
growth, initiate a participatory approach; and develop team spirit, commitment, 
and ownership.  Prepare the preliminary project framework and a proposed work 
plan. The findings of Phase I will be reviewed and approved at the first tripartite 
meeting  including  the  Government,  ADB,  the  consultants,  and  the  advisory 
group. 
(ii)  Commence  the  fieldwork,  and  progressively  develop  the  project  framework, 
following ADB's guidelines throughout the preparation of the project. Assess the 
suitability of the Government’s priority areas for inclusion in the project activities. 
(iii)  Determine the scale and scope of any additional poverty and social interventions 
that may be required in ensuring that the Project is gender and poverty sensitive, 
following ADB’s Handbook for Poverty and Social Analysis. Identify social and 
gender factors affecting project risk and viability. 
(iv)  Assess the status and technology used for high-value crop production in Nepal, 
including the suitability of current production areas. Identify opportunities for the 
introduction and expansion of new crops and indicate suitable areas for this 
introduction  and  expansion.  Review  and  identify  the  trends  in  production, 
management practices, and services to farmers. Assess the impact of previous 
development  activities  on  commercialization,  income  growth  and  poverty 
reduction, and incorporate the lessons learned. 
(v)  Determine the need, and recommend programs and support, for research in the 
development of new improved planting/seed materials and associated production 
and management technologies and their dissemination to farmers. 
(vi)  Review the postharvest activities associated with high-value crop production in 
Nepal.  Recommend  appropriate  systems  and  technologies  for  the  improved 
handling, storage, grading, quality control, and transport of harvested material. 
Indicate research priorities and mechanisms for the development and application 
of new approaches and technologies. Identify opportunities and mechanisms for 
agribusiness  development  and  adding  value,  especially  by  smallholder  or 
landless farmers, women, and farmers' groups. 
(vii)  Assess the capacities of the various stakeholders in agricultural production in 
both the public and private sectors. Make recommendations for capacity building 
to  improve  planning,  participation,  coordination,  management,  and 
implementation. 
(viii)  Review mechanisms used to assess farmer needs and recommend systems 
based  on  bottom-up  participatory  approaches  that  will  result  in  demand-led 
research and development and more effective extension services and training of

Appendix 4  13 
farmers. Investigate systems being used for farmer/user group mobilization and 
recommend approaches, mechanisms, and support required for the sustainable 
mobilization of farmer, women, water user, market and entrepreneurial groups 
under the Project. 
(ix)  Review the management of water in the various irrigation systems being used in 
the project area and recommend inputs, technologies, and management and 
organizational mechanisms that will improve the distribution and use of water. 
(x)  Investigate the status of existing irrigation systems and farm-to-market roads in 
the project area and indicate any supplemental assistance that may be necessary 
to close critical gaps in road and irrigation facilities impeding the production 
activities of project farmers. 
(xi)  Evaluate the influence of service providers including microfinance services on 
agriculture development, particularly the changing roles of the public and private 
sectors in the delivery of those services. Suggest improvements in the availability 
of credit to farmers and entrepreneurs, paying particular attention to interest rates 
and service charges. 
(xii)  Critically  assess  the  underlying  factors  of  an  effective  marketing  system 
(infrastructure information and incentive structure of different market participants) 
and the pricing mechanism from the demand side to farm gate; and recommend 
improvements  such  as  the  development  of  collection  systems,  fairer  trading 
mechanisms,  better  storage  and  handling  facilities,  effective  quality  control, 
improved  transportation,  expansion  of  wholesale  markets,  and  training  in 
management and organization. 
(xiii)  Assess current and future supply and demand prospects for high-value crops and 
their value-added products, in both the domestic and export markets, and identify 
new markets. Prepare postharvest and marketing strategies and plans, including 
adding value for project outputs. Review the type and volume of border trade and 
indicate adjustments required for Nepal to join the World Trade Organization 
(WTO). Recommend activities for disseminating market information to producers 
and traders, and for developing awareness among the general public of the 
quality, nutrition, and hygiene aspects of agricultural produce. 
(xiv)  Examine the status of quarantine management of plant diseases for incoming 
plant matter and seeds, identify weaknesses, and make recommendations for 
research and strengthening of control programs, especially when Nepal joins 
WTO. 
(xv)  Review the capability, adequacy, and management of manpower resources in the 
public and private sectors involved in agricultural development; and formulate 
strategies for their improvement and expansion, including education and training 
needs. In particular, define mechanisms for the evolution of DOA as a facilitator 
of the development process utilizing partnership arrangements with the private 
sector  and  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs)  and  a  people-centered 
participatory approach that incorporates demand-led development. 
(xvi)  Review the impact of decentralization on the activities of DOA and recommend 
support for management and coordination of agricultural development under the 
Project. Especially, identify policy changes required for greater private sector 
involvement and agribusiness development in high-value agriculture production 
and  marketing,  and  suggest  approaches  (including  possible  industry  funding

14  Appendix 4 
mechanisms)  for  more  effective  review  and  enforcement  of  regulations  and 
quality control to ensure a fair market place. 
(xvii)  Delineate inputs for improving project management through capacity building for 
better planning, coordination, project implementation, monitoring, and evaluation. 
Finalize a BME component for the Project that provides for qualitative feedback 
from farmers and other beneficiaries. Examine environmental protection policies 
and their implementation in the development of the agriculture sector, following 
ADB’s Guidelines on Environmental Assessment. 
(xviii)  Conduct the second workshop to review the findings of Phase II, and confirm 
consensus on the details proposed in the feasibility study for an agricultural 
development  project.  Commence  the  preparation  of  the  draft  final  report, 
incorporating the findings from the fieldwork outlined earlier and the deliberations 
of the advisory group. 
C.  Phase  III―Completion  of  the  Feasibility  Study  and  Initial  Environmental 
Examination (1.5 months) 
 
5.  The consultants, in collaboration with the advisory group, will complete the detailed draft 
final report begun in Phase II, building on the findings and lessons learned from the Agriculture 
Sector Performance Review and other projects in the sector. The project framework will be 
finalized and the draft final report, including the project framework, will be reviewed at a meeting 
of the advisory group about 2 weeks after the commencement of Phase III. Any additional 
suggestions or comments will be confirmed at a final tripartite meeting. The feasibility study will 
be finalized incorporating these comments and submitted about 4 weeks later. During Phase III, 
the consultants will do the following: 
(i)  Finalize  a  feasibility  study  for  an  investment  project  suitable  for  external 
financing.  The  Project  will  be  based  on  systems  learning  for  participatory 
development and will focus on the commercialization of agriculture for high-value 
crop production, and the development of agribusinesses. It will pay particular 
attention to the requirements of smallholders and women farmers and encourage 
sustainable development of the private sector. 
(ii)  Describe  the  project  scope  in  detail  using  an  integrated  systems  approach, 
including comprehensive descriptions of the inputs and outputs, strategies, policy 
recommendations,  training  and  research  requirements,  and  the  underlying 
technical assumptions. Define the project areas and the project beneficiaries for 
the  project  components/activities  clearly  indicating  the  timing,  content,  and 
mechanisms for review and monitoring of the development process. Define the 
institutional  mechanisms  for  adopting  a  process  approach,  and  detail  the 
mechanisms/modalities for the incorporation of participatory planning processes 
into the management and implementation, clearly indicating how DOA will adapt 
to a role as a facilitator and regulator of development. 
(iii)  Prepare detailed cost estimates for the Project using the COSTAB computer 
software. Prepare model farm enterprise budgets using the FARMOD computer 
software. Identify project beneficiaries by income groups, and indicate the likely 
distribution of project benefits among the various groups. In addition to farm 
producers,  financial  analysis  will  also  be  undertaken  for  processors, 
agribusinesses, and marketing agents to assess the likely incentive structure for 
these stakeholders. Prepare an overall implementation schedule of the various 
project  components  with  supporting  Gantt  charts.  Finally,  provide  detailed 
economic and financial analysis including estimates of economic and financial

Appendix 4  15 
internal rates of return as specified in Sections 35 and 36 of ADB’s Operations 
Manual. Highlight the economic impact on the socially disadvantaged members 
of the community. 
(iv)  Describe strategies for institutional strengthening, particularly in respect of policy 
support,  manpower  development,  and  supply  of  input  and  services.  Indicate 
mechanisms  that  allow  for  the  establishment  of  partnerships  between 
government  agencies  and  the  private  sector  in  development  activities.  Give 
detailed recommendations for training and for consultant and NGO/community-
based organization support, including their detailed terms of reference. 
(v)  Indicate  the  environmental  impacts  of  the  project  and  recommend  remedial 
measures. Prepare an initial environmental examination (IEE) and summary IEE 
for attachment to the feasibility study of the Project, in accordance with ADB's 
Environmental  Guidelines  for  Selected  Agricultural  and  Natural  Resources 
Development Projects. Finalize a gender action plan for the proposed Project, 
following  ADB’s  guidelines,  and  outline  the  design  and  support  for  a  more 
effective project BME system including clearly identifying monitoring indicators 
with the requirements given in ADB's guidelines for monitoring and evaluation of 
projects. 
(vi)  Prepare  an  executive  summary  in  the  format  of  an  ADB  report  and 
recommendation to the president and submit the feasibility study and executive 
summary  in  printed  and  electronic  versions  using  Microsoft  2000  software 
programs. 
D.  Reporting Requirements 
6.  The consultants, under the direction of the team leader, will submit the following reports 
to the Government and the ADB: 
(i)  The team leader and deputy team leader will jointly submit an inception report at 
the end of Phase I for review and comment. 
(ii)  The social analysis/mobilization team will submit a work plan 1 week after their 
fielding and a detailed report, 2 weeks after the completion of their fieldwork. 
(iii)  An interim report on the status of the fieldwork and the developing project outline 
will be submitted 1 week prior to the review mission in the middle of Phase II. 
(iv)  The detailed project outline will be reviewed at the second workshop at the end of 
Phase II, and submitted to ADB and the Government. 
(v)  The draft final report will be submitted 1 week before the final meeting of the 
advisory group and the third tripartite meeting, in the second week of Phase III. 
(vi)  The final report will be submitted at the end of Phase III.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  BME  –  benefit monitoring and evaluation 
  DDC  –  district development committee 
  DOA  –  Department of Agriculture 
  GDI  –  gender-related development index 
  HDI  –  human development index 
  IEE  –  initial environmental examination 
  IPSA  –  Initial Poverty and Social Analysis 
  NGO  –  nongovernment organization 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  TOR  –  terms of reference 
  VDC  –  village development committee 
  WTO  –  World Trade Organization 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
NOTES 
 
(i)  The fiscal year (FY) of the Government ends on 15 July.  
(ii)  In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
This report was prepared by a team consisting of Pratima Dayal, Team Leader; Snimer 
Sahni,  Sr.  Project  Economist;  Govinda  Gewali,  Project  Implementation  Officer;  and 
Melinda Good, Counsel.
